content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." The term 'foreign private fund adviser' under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 refers to an investment adviser who has no place of business in the United States, fewer than 15 clients in the US in the past year, and assets under management from US clients of less than $25,000,000. The term 'foreign private fund adviser' under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 refers to an investment adviser with assets under management from US clients of less than $25,000,000, who does not hold itself out as an investment adviser to the public in the US or act as an adviser to registered investment companies. The term 'foreign private fund adviser' under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 refers to an investment adviser with assets under management from US clients of less than $25,000,000, who does not act as an investment adviser to any investment company registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers, including small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers who solely advise small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, entities that have received notice from the Small Business Administration to qualify for a license, or applicants related to licensed small business investment companies. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers related to licensed small business investment companies applying for another license. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers related to licensed small business investment companies applying for another license. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports with the Commission regarding private funds advised by them. Investment advisers registered under the Act must maintain records and file reports with the Commission regarding private funds they advise, as deemed necessary for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission can share this information with the Federal Reserve System and other entities identified for systemic risk. The Commission can share reports and records of private funds maintained by registered investment advisers with the Federal Reserve System and other entities responsible for systemic risk assessment. The records and reports of private funds advised by registered investment advisers must include information such as assets under management, leverage usage, counterparty credit risk exposures, and trading positions. The SEC requires private funds advised by registered investment advisers to disclose assets under management, leverage usage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant information determined necessary for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The SEC may require private fund advisers to report additional information deemed necessary for investor protection and systemic risk assessment, with different reporting requirements for various classes of advisers. The SEC may set different reporting requirements for private fund advisers based on the types or sizes of funds advised, considering public interest and systemic risk. Advisers must maintain records of private funds for periods specified by the Commission. Investment advisers registered under the Act must maintain records of private funds for specified periods as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Records are subject to periodic examinations. Investment advisers registered under the Act must maintain records of private funds for specified periods as prescribed by the Commission. Records are subject to periodic and special examinations by the Commission or its representatives. Advisers must make copies or extracts of records available to the Commission upon request. Investment advisers registered under the Act must provide records to the Commission upon request without undue effort. The Commission shares information with the Federal Reserve and other entities with systemic risk responsibility. The Commission shares reports and information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for assessing systemic risk of private funds. Investment advisers registered under the Act must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, prospective investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds. The information obtained by the Board or other entities for assessing systemic risk of private funds must be kept confidential. Investment advisers registered under the Act must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, prospective investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds as required by the Commission. The Commission is not obligated to disclose any report or information contained therein. The Commission is not compelled to disclose any report or information required to be filed under this subsection, ensuring confidentiality. The Commission is not required to disclose information to other Federal agencies or courts, ensuring confidentiality. SEC. 5 amends the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 by eliminating a disclosure provision. SEC. 6 exempts and requires reporting by venture capital fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the condition of maintaining records and providing necessary reports to the Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the condition of maintaining records and providing necessary reports to the Commission. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. The Commission will also require exempted advisers to maintain reporting. Private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000 are exempt from registration requirements under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. The Commission will require exempted advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports for investor protection. Additionally, regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers. The Commission will prescribe regulations for mid-sized private fund advisers, taking into account fund size, governance, and investment strategy to determine systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures reflecting the level of risk posed by such funds. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions, including defining technical terms and classifying persons and matters based on size. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on various factors and prescribe different requirements for different classes. It can also ascribe different meanings to terms, excluding the term 'client'. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on various factors, prescribe different requirements, and ascribe different meanings to terms, excluding the term 'client'. The Commission, in consultation with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will establish rules for reports to be filed under the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 within 12 months of its enactment. The Commission, in consultation with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will establish rules for reports to be filed under the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 within 12 months of its enactment, including the form and content of reports required by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under the Act. A report containing the findings will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Effective date and transition period provisions are also included. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. Section 205(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
